channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: France and Germany Celebrate 50th Anniversary of Élysée Treaty
item.description: Half a century after they signed a historic peace treaty, France and Germany still have their differences, but war between the onetime enemies is now hard to imagine.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel, left, and President François Hollande in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: Some Syrian Kurds Resist Assad, Defying Conventional Views
item.description: Thousands have taken up arms on the rebels’ side, saying that they have also suffered under the current government under President Bashar al-Assad.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Kurds who are fighting against the Assad regime in Alghooz, Syria.

item.title: U.N. Agency Warns of Rising Unemployment
item.description: A report from the International Labor Organization predicted jobless levels to rise to 202 million worldwide this year, and said that government budget-balancing was hurting employment.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Perusing job postings in Milan. More than 197 million people worldwide are unemployed.

item.title: Galina Stepanenko Is Bolshoi’s Acting Director After Attack
item.description: Sergei Filin, who was severely burned last week when acid was thrown in his face, said he had asked the Bolshoi theater’s general director for protection after receiving threats but was refused.
item.dc:creator: By SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Reverberations After the Bolshoi Attack
item.description: While the investigation of the attack on the director of the Bolshoi continues, the news media has focused on the long history of internecine war at the ballet company.
item.dc:creator: By ROSLYN SUCLAS
item.media:description: The Bolshoi Theater illuminated for its reopening ceremony in 2011.

item.title: The Lede Blog: Prince Harry Compares War to PlayStation, and Taliban Are Not Amused
item.description: A Taliban spokesman said that Prince Harry must have "mental problems," after the royal said that killing militants from an Apache helicopter was similar to playing video games.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Exit Polls in Israel Suggest Netanyahu’s Showing Is Weaker Than Expected
item.description: While Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel remained likely to serve a third term, a surprise surge by a new centrist party indicated he would be under pressure to form a more moderate governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: A polling station on Tuesday in the West Bank Jewish settlement of Elon Moreh, near Nablus.

item.title: DealBook: China’s Focus on Aerospace Raises Security Questions
item.description: As Beijing's leaders try to find new ways to invest $3 trillion of foreign reserves, aerospace deals prove attractive even as they give China's neighbors a reason to wonder about security threats.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker in an Airbus facility in Tianjin, China, that completes four planes a month, mostly for state-run carriers.

item.title: Burst of Iraq Violence Amid Political Crisis
item.description: A series of attacks that left at least 24 Iraqis dead came as Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia claimed responsibility for the assassination of a Sunni lawmaker last week.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Greek Prosecutors Seek Inquiry Over Deficit Claims
item.description: The prosecutors asked for a criminal inquiry into the head of Elstat, Greece’s statistical authority, and two of his subordinates, over claims that they manipulated budget figures.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Hamas Paints Malaysian Premier’s Visit as Stand Against Israel
item.description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia visited the Gaza Strip on what he called a humanitarian mission but Hamas portrayed as a “declaration for breaking the Israeli siege on Gaza.”
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia, second from left, in Gaza City on Tuesday.

item.title: Car Bombs in Iraq Kill at Least 17
item.description: A string of car bomb attacks in and around Baghdad wounded dozens Tuesday, deepening fears of an increase in violence as sectarian tensions simmer in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: WORLD: Polls Open Across Israel
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is widely expected to win re-election, but some voters still say they are undecided and many lack enthusiasm for Israeli politics.

item.title: India Ink: Supreme Court to Consider Moving Delhi Gang Rape Trial on Wednesday
item.description: The court is scheduled Thursday to hear arguments on the charges against the five men who are accused of raping a 23-year-old woman.
item.dc:creator: By NIHARIKA MANDHANA

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: Jan. 22
item.description: Former Haryana chief minister and son get a ten year sentence on corruption charges by a Delhi court.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: France’s National Library Hopes to Buy Sade’s ‘120 Days’
item.description: France’s National Library is negotiating to buy the manuscript of “The 120 Days of Sodom,” the Marquis de Sade’s tale of rape, murder and torture, which Sade believed was lost in the storming of the Bastille.
item.dc:creator: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

item.title: DealBook: Despite Signs of Progress in the Euro Zone, Fears of Complacency Linger
item.description: Europe's political leaders have taken important steps to improve spending discipline among euro members, but have yet to address some serious flaws in the structure of the euro zone.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN and JACK EWING
item.media:description: Preparations are under way for the World Economic Forum, for which academics, executives and various experts will gather in Davos, Switzerland.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Two Views on Liberal Arts
item.description: Which serves students better: the American-style liberal arts education? Or the more focused European and Asian models?
item.dc:creator: By JOYCE LAU

item.title: Russians Fleeing Syria Cross Into Lebanon
item.description: A Russian diplomat told the Interfax news service that around 100 Russians were leaving Syria as the government activates plans to remove its citizens from the conflict zone.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Lebanese soldiers at the Masnaa border on Tuesday escort Russian nationals who were evacuated from Damascus.

item.title: At War Blog: Victims of Sexual Trauma Harness the Calming Power of Horses
item.description: A free horse program, near Twin Cities, offers women veterans a space to heal outside the company of men.
item.dc:creator: By JESSICA MADOR

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: It's Davos Time Again
item.description: Andrew Ross Sorkin says Davos predictions don't always come true and Alison Smale, the executive editor of the IHT, points out that crisis is the new normal. All amid a growing sense at Davos that bankers have suffered enough "abuse."
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: A Swiss Air Force Super Puma helicopter takes off after a Davos media presentation on Jan. 22.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: France and Germany: 'No Longer a Couple, but Divorce Is Impossible.'
item.description: Amid celebrations of the golden anniversary of an historic friendship treaty that anchored European construction, Europe's power couple finds its relationship on the rocks.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Angela Merkel and Francois Hollande in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: Japan Makes Overture to China in Islands Dispute
item.description: A member of Japan’s coalition government arrived in Beijing Tuesday to try to calm the escalating dispute between the two countries over contested islands in the East China Sea.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Oscar Anticipation in the Subtitle Category
item.description: After a record number of submissions in the foreign film category and most of the European awards now accounted for, how does the competition for "Amour" stack up?
item.dc:creator: By HANNAH OLIVENNES
item.media:description: Emmanuelle Riva as Anne in "Amour," from Austria.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Hong Kong Holiday Makeover, in Lights
item.description: Hong Kong goes into overdrive for the holiday season, as Christmas lights morph into Chinese New Year lights.
item.dc:creator: By BETTINA WASSENER
item.media:credit: Alex Hofford for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Skyscrapers in Hong Kong decorated for Christmas in December.
